div.p: Greetings in the Lord. I diligently took care of the letters sent to me, which I received on the night of March 9th; for early in the morning, I went to the house of Maurus, who is now in Solothurn, called to the Swiss Diet, where military matters will be discussed, and I found the postman mounting his horse, who undoubtedly delivered them on the same day, as he had promised. I also sent another letter to Strasbourg on the same day, written by Montius, through a trustworthy man, our fellow citizen.

I will send the books you requested when I find a suitable courier. I promise nothing about the German booklets; for they are not available in any bookstore. I think I have two, which, if I find them after searching the library, I will lend to you.

The situation with our Oporinus is as follows: He published a booklet by Naus√©e, which they do not want to sell in Basel, and some idle people have stirred up some kind of tragedy about a new booklet printed by Oporinus against our religion. The senate requested the booklets when he was thrown into prison; the brothers read them and said to the senate that there is nothing bad in the dialogues nor anything against our religion, except that we are called heretics.
He was therefore released without any fine imposed; however, he was ordered to collect the booklets he had distributed, which is impossible, and to give them to the senate, which will never happen.
Thus, judgments are often made without properly examining the matter and by those who do not understand what is being discussed.
If he had shown the booklet to the deputies, he would not have incurred any danger.
The parliament of Ensisheim captured many soldiers, whom they beheaded; the Imperial and Ferdinandine forces are completely mad.
You undoubtedly know that Baron von Solms was captured by the Landgrave and taken to France. Mr. Schertlin has a large number of soldiers and is setting out for Lorraine against the Emperor's wishes.

The younger son of the Landgrave came to us on March 6th and is staying at a public inn and barely escaped; he was dressed in women's clothing and rode in a cheap carriage so as not to be recognized. The notable captain Hans von Salzburg was captured by the Ensisheim forces, which greatly troubles Schertlin, a very good man, who will undoubtedly take revenge on them. Herr Bastian has made a green coat, embroidered on the sleeves with: P P P, which means: fight for the fatherland, and on the insignia, he has in golden letters: Freedom of Germany, on the shooting banner a gun, upon which a burning rooster. You can guess what this signifies.
To the well-learned gentleman Heinrich Bullinger, pastor in Zurich, my gracious lord, to his hands. Zurich.
